briefOverview: A revelation calling willing disciples to labor in God’s work and outlining the character required to build Zion.
summary: God announces that a great and marvelous work is imminent and urges hearers to heed His powerful word. Using harvest imagery, He invites any who desire to reap to labor diligently now, promising salvation to those who do. He affirms that whoever thrusts in their sickle to reap is called of God and reiterates the promise that those who ask and knock will receive and find the way opened. The Lord commands the seeker to keep His commandments and to help establish Zion. He broadens the message to all with such desires, teaching that only the humble, loving, faithful, hopeful, charitable, and temperate can truly assist. The revelation concludes with Christ identifying Himself as the light and life of the world and confirming the call to heed His words.
externalContext: This revelation is historically connected with early 1829 events during the translation of the Book of Mormon in Harmony, Pennsylvania. Latter-day Saint histories associate it with Joseph Knight Sr., a supporter who supplied Joseph Smith and Oliver Cowdery with material needs during translation. Early revelations often follow a pattern: a personal call, universalized to anyone with righteous desire, and an emphasis on character qualifications for service. “Zion” in early Latter-day Saint usage denotes the covenant community living God’s law, later tied to gathering and building a holy society.
externalReferences: The harvest imagery echoes Jesus’ words in John 4:35 (“fields…white already to harvest”), a motif also used in Doctrine and Covenants 4:1–7 to describe qualifications for service. The description of God’s word as “sharper than a two-edged sword” closely parallels Hebrews 4:12. The promise “ask…seek…knock” reflects Jesus’ teaching in Matthew 7:7–8. The self-identification as “the light” recalls John 8:12, and the cluster “faith, hope, and charity” resonates with 1 Corinthians 13:13.
practicalQuestions: Where is my present “field” to harvest, and what concrete steps can I take to labor diligently today?
How can I cultivate humility, charity, and temperance so I am fit to assist in God’s work?
What practices can help me actively “ask,” “seek,” and “knock” in prayer and action this week?
In what ways can I contribute to establishing Zion in my home, congregation, or community?
How does viewing calling as linked to willingness and work change my approach to service?
uncertainAreas: The historical addressee (commonly identified as Joseph Knight Sr.) is not named in the text; while well-attested in Latter-day Saint history, this identification is external to the chapter. The scope of “called” (general versus formal calling) is implied by action and desire here but could be interpreted differently in broader ecclesial contexts.
